utterances: He had to come home because there were no accessible hotel rooms.
This is light years, in legal terms, before there was an Americans with Disabilities Act, before there were civil rights for people with disabilities.
He's doing this in the early '50s and '60s.
He turned down a cabinet post under President Carter for reasons that it would be instructive for us to know now.
Yeah.
He turned it down because at those days, there was no guarantee of health insurance if you went back.
There was no Health Insurance Portability Act.
His fabric of his life would've been at risk.
Do you know what cabinet post he was offered?
I don't know for sure, but I think it was secretary of transportation.
That would've been the natural thing.
I do know that he did watch the 1968 election returns with Hubert Humphrey, and that had the election gone the other way, he would've been chief of staff.
And I know also that Humphrey had promised him that one of the first executive orders would've been to make buildings accessible.
Beginning in the 1970s, he would appear on the muscular dystrophy telethon with Jerry Lewis.

Jerry, you know, this is my 50th year in a wheelchair, and beginning 14 years ago, I have never stood taller than I have being with you in this cause this way.
For somebody who didn't like to leave fingerprints, who was a private man, what was it like for him to go on the - I mean he'd became known as what, Jerry's older kid?
We know this will be the first time, Corey.
I believe you're back with us, right?
Yes.
All right.
This is the first time as - that we will get a chance to see a substantive block of black voters choose on the Democratic side at least between presumably Obama and Hillary Clinton.
Do you have a sense of how that is going in South Carolina right now?
Well, at this point, South Carolina is the battleground for so many different reasons.
Obviously, blacks make up half the turnout in the Democratic primary.
But beyond that, this result will set the tone for how the rest of the South may vote and provide significant momentum for the winner heading into the February 5th primaries.
As far as the black vote here, the Clinton and Obama camps have taken sort of different approaches.
The Clinton campaign had locked up early endorsements from prominent black politicians and ministers.
While the Obama campaign - because they initially lacked the name recognition - built a large field organization aimed at reaching black voters directly in their communities.
And at this point, Obama has now taken the lead from Clinton in the polls among African-American voters and Democratic voters overall in the state.
And most significantly perhaps is that Obama now is tied with Clinton in the polls among women.
You know, it's one thing to think back to when Jesse Jackson first ran for the presidency and how that energized the black community, not only in terms of debate but also in terms of voter turnout.
Is there any sense that Obama's presence in South Carolina is going to affect the turnout particularly among black voters, Corey?
I think so.

There's every sign of that and that he is going after young black voters who have never voted before but what's also significant is that his huge portion of his get-out-the-vote effort relies on volunteers who are unpaid, who are black, who are under 35, and have never participated in the process before.
So that's one issue.
The other issue that the more it has become contested by both candidates, the more attention South Carolina gets, the more they get the attention particularly of the rural blacks.
So as long as this is a hot battleground, there is every indication that this could be - if not a record turnout among blacks in South Carolina but a big one.
Let's move on to another topic.
I'm going to come to you on this, Michael Fletcher.
President Bush announced that this week he thinks there would be a signed peace treaty between Israel and Palestine by the time that he leaves office.
Talk, if you will, about the timing of such an announcement and the attention that it has generated in the press.
Is it skepticism, optimism, what?
Well, I think among the press, there's a lot of skepticism because this is the same President Bush who, for so long, you know, wasn't really deeply involved in the Middle East peace process.
I mean, they laid the roadmap, as they call it, in the early part of his administration.
But since then, it has been a much of hands-off issue for President Bush.

Then, of course, I mean, the Baker-Hamilton Commission and, you know, mentioned that the United States should take a more active role in trying to bring about some kind of, you know, broker some kind of long-term deal between the Palestinians and Israelis as a way to kind of, you know, take the energy out of the sort of anti-Americanism in the Middle East and among Islamics generally.
And so his ethic, you see President Bush's action motivated by that most of all.
But I don't know that if, you know, it's going to deliver what he says because there are a lot of hurdles in the way and the things he's talking about what to do of Jerusalem, things like that.
I don't think these things will be settled because these are old issues that have deep-seated feelings on both sides.
Theola, if he is successful, it would certainly be a boost not only for President Bush but for the Republican Party as well.
But if it falls apart, especially before the November elections, how might the presidential campaign be affected, if at all?
You know, Tony, it's very interesting.
We have talked before about the time that I spent in Iraq.

And as I watch this presidential campaign, I think that the Arab world is very closely watching this election because Bush to them, in some respects, has been a pretty significant president in terms of influencing policy there, obviously, with the invasion into Iraq and some of his other comments about neighboring states and such.

And so I'm not sure if something is signed or not kind of how that might play out because, largely, I've seen and heard the candidates talk very opaquely about Iraq and about the Arab world because right now, the message seems to be focused on change and which candidate can actually claim the mantle of change and that is - and that to me is also on the GOP side as well as the Democrats.
Let me let our audience know what we are doing.
You're listening to NPR's NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Tony Cox, in for Farai Chideya today.
If you are just tuning in, with me on today's Roundtable are Michael Fletcher, Theola Labbe, both with the Washington Post, and Corey Dade with The Wall Street Journal.
Corey, an outgoing president is in a tough spot, isn't he, when he comes to leading the nation and at the same time trying to help his party stay in the White House during a tough close race.
How effective is the president at being presidential and partisan now that we're in the middle of the - at the beginning of the primary season?
Well, I think President Bush has shown no problem in being partisan.
I don't think that will change going forward.
I think what's significant is that none of the Republican candidates for the nomination have been able to latch themselves to his record.

They have tried to find ways to express support for continued occupation of Iraq and pressing the war, but at the same time, have distanced themselves from the president, and I think that will continue.
Michael Fletcher is national economics writer and former White House correspondent for the Washington Post.
Theola Labbe, an education reporter, also for the Washington Post.
Both she and Mike joined us from the Washington Post Studios in our nation's Capitol.
And Corey Dade with the Wall Street Journal.

As far as Bush is concerned, he has given every indication that he is going to try to give the Republican Party some victories because it's not just about the presidential holding on to the White House for the Republicans.
It's also about gaining seats in the House, if they can, and holding to their slight advantage in the Senate.
So this has reverberations for all the congressional elections that are going on this year.
Well, Michael, you covered the White House before.

Is there a point at which you determine, as a member of the press corps, that you see the White House prerogative beginning to move and diverging directions because, as Corey was just talking about, at one hand, you have to remain presidential; on the other, you have to protect the party, if you can; and thirdly, you have to try to protect the seats in Congress.
You know, it's been interesting of this White House because I think a lot of Republicans in Congress actually are frustrated with President Bush.
Before the midterm elections, for example, many Republicans are hoping he would make some kind of significant move in terms of change in strategy in Iraq.
And he waited until after the elections to, you know, to fire Rumsfeld and things like that.
So this president has been somewhat unique while he's -you know, he's been kind of pushing his agenda, pushing for his foreign policy.
And I think with the rationale being that if he's successful that, in the end, will help Republicans.
But along the way, he is really kind of broken of what a lot of congressional leaders would have liked to have seen.
They say he doesn't listen to them.
President Bush has done a lot of spending as president, and that's left a lot of Republicans vulnerable in Congress.
So he's been kind of a president interested in furthering his presidency.

When the president was reelected to office in 2004, he declared that he had earned a political capital - this is my last question about that and we're going to move on to another topic - and he intended to spend that capital.
Theola, although he seems to be spending it now, how much capital does the current president currently have?

I think when you wake up to headlines about Countrywide stocks falling precipitously and then needing a buyout, I think that those sorts of things are tied directly to Bush, and that capital is dwindling, if not, you know, dead.
I mean someone once said famously, it's the economy, stupid.
And I think that, clearly, that that has emerged of the story of 2008.
And everyone now is looking ahead because of this contest for president.
And because, as Michael said, Bush has been so good about thinking about Bush and then his legacy, I think that folks are now saying, look, we went into Iraq.
We had a president who said, I am the decider.
And now, years later, I may not be able to refinance my mortgage.
And so I want somebody new.
I want change.
I'm just really not sure who that might be.

Well, at this point, you know, the president is the lame duck.

So the fact that they are trying to shift to Israeli relations with Palestine, and those issues kind of demonstrates that, Iraq or - excuse me - Iran is going to be less important going forward because you have a National Intelligence Estimate that revealed sort of the status of Iran's nuclear development program.
